talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Did the minister read the Department of Health and Aged Care's submission to the Senate Community Affairs Committee inquiry into the private health insurance rebate before it was submitted? Is the minister aware that this submission disclosed that the all-up cost of the new scheme will be $1,688 million in the year 2001, including previously undisclosed additional costs to Medicare? Minister, are you aware that the Secretary of the Department of Health and Aged Care withdrew key parts of his submission after the $200 million increase in the cost of the initiative got media coverage? Was your office involved in the discussions which led to the amendment of the submission?

—I did not read the submission because I did not seek to influence it. My understanding is that the department made a mistake and it put in a correction. I could not tell you the exact role of my office. I do not know.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. I seek clarification as to whether the government's plan to establish a new tax system will reduce marginal income tax rates for average earners. What income tax rates will average earners pay if personal income tax is not reduced?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I can say to the honourable member that, under the Labor Party's tax system, average earners are now facing a marginal income tax rate of 43 cents in the dollar, plus the Medicare levy of 44½ cents in the dollar. The Labor Party opposes the reduction of marginal income tax rates because it refuses to support the reform of the Australian taxation system. The Labor Party opposes the reduction of marginal income tax rates on average earners.
—You can't be that arrogant!

—The member for Corio does not seem to know what his own policy is. The Labor Party opposes the reduction of marginal income tax rates for average earners. It would not be the case that the tax rate was 43c for the average earner in Australia if a previous attempt to lower income tax had gone through. The House would be well aware that, prior to the 1993 election, by an act called `an act to amend the law relating to income tax' in 1992, this parliament passed a law reducing the tax to 30 per cent on what are, today, average weekly earnings. That was not a promise—that was l-a-w.

answer.para: That l-a-w tax cut of 1992 was never put in place, not even for one day. It is still on the statute books. The Labor Party passed an act to reduce income tax rates. They said it was l-a-w. It is still on the statute books and it did not apply for one day. As a consequence, average earners in Australia are now facing a 43c income tax marginal rate. Only if this government's tax reform is put through will average earners in Australia get lower marginal income tax rates.

In addition to the relief for average income earners and families—which Labor opposes—there is good reason on economic grounds to cut marginal income tax rates. Cutting marginal income tax rates will help this country in relation to productivity, savings, incentives and the reduction of effective marginal tax rates. Lower personal income tax rates are good economic policy in themselves, but they are being opposed by the Australian Labor Party. On this side, we welcome the opportunity to make good and do better than the fraud of the Labor Party—when it took away the income tax l-a-w—and give families and average income earners lower income taxes and to see a new tax system for a new century.

talk.start.para: —My question is again to the Minister for Health and Aged Care. I renew the question to him as to whether or not his office saw or in any way sought to influence the submission from his department to that committee of inquiry. Further, does the minister concede that the department's amended health insurance submission still shows that the total cost will reach $1.7 billion because of a cost blow-out in the existing means-tested rebate and an extra $80 million cost to Medicare as a result of additional private patients making claims for medical expenses in private hospitals? Does this new and increased estimate include the additional cost of meeting pharmaceutical costs claimed by additional patients in private hospitals?
—I do not concede anything and, quite frankly, I have not even seen the correction. It is a matter for my department. I do not seek to influence what they do.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Has the minister seen reports that the minor parties in the other house are prepared to offer a compromise on the government's private health insurance rebate in an attempt to avoid its defeat at the hands of the Labor Party? Will the government be compromising on the rebate as presented to the people?
—How would he know? The department would have to tell him.
—Order! The member for Hotham will exercise considerably more restraint or find himself warned.

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I have seen a proposal put out by the Democrats. The government will not be accepting it. The proposal relies very heavily on so-called experts. Some of these experts have a clear vested interest in a public dominated health care system, such as the Australian Hospitals Association and the Doctors Reform Society. Others among the rest quoted have a stated preference for a residual role only for the private sector, such as the Consumers Health Forum, the Council for the Ageing, Mr Roy Harvey and Professor Douglas. This is essentially a personal preference as distinct from any academic or intellectual position.

answer.para: The Democrats' option would not work. First of all, our plan is to encourage all Australians to take out private health insurance. The universal nature of Medicare is that every taxpayer pays for Medicare whether they need it or whether they don't. It is only fair, then, that every taxpayer should receive a benefit if they choose to make an extra contribution of their own income, whether they use it or not. Secondly, the Democrats' proposal would have an adverse impact on the middle and higher income people who are in fact the largest group of people falling out of private health insurance. Thirdly, those higher income earners are people who by and large do not draw heavily on private health insurance. Lower income earners, usually because of their age, are heavy drawers on the private health system. So that balance of having higher income people who are lower users maintains community rating for those lower income, generally older, higher users. The fact is that if you artificially bring in a whole lot of heavy drawers on the system you will push premiums up, not down.

Fourthly, the Democrats' proposal would be highly complex. We have found one of the drawbacks of the current health incentive scheme is its complexity, that you have to apply for it annually. The public, as we have found in research we have done, is very wary of a means test, believing that even if they qualify it may not be for them. If we take up the Democrats' proposal, we will not treat any of the problems, we will only be treating the symptoms, and we will find we are back to exactly where we started.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Is the minister aware of the evidence provided by Professor John Deeble to the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee inquiry—
—You have to bring him into it!
—Yes, the architect of Medicare.
—Order! The member for Jagajaga has the call and has every right to be heard in silence.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. Is the minister aware of evidence provided by Professor John Deeble to the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee inquiry where he calculated that 90 per cent of the benefits of the private health insurance rebate will go to existing members of private health insurance funds and a whopping $900 million will go to existing members who are above the income limit of $70,000 for the existing means-tested rebate? What does this do to help ordinary Australians struggling to get into a public hospital?

—That clearly shows that the Labor Party does not understand the basic problems with health. It is more of their carping, negative opposition for the sake of it. What it will do is maintain community rating, prop up the people who are dropping out of health insurance faster than anything else, and slow down the rate of premiums and put them off for a couple of months. The earlier premium increases at a higher level than they would be otherwise will be absolutely your fault.

—My question is also addressed to the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Can the minister advise the House what sort of items are included in ancillary cover in private health insurance policies? What is the minister's response to suggestions that these items are only sought by wealthy people?

—I thank the honourable member for her question. I have seen such proposals as put out by the Labor Party. Again, they fail to understand the complexity of the whole system. I have a copy of a letter from the Australian Podiatry Association. Podiatry is one of the reasonably large users of ancillary benefits. This letter states:

answer.para: The members of the Australian Podiatry Association in South Australia wish to express their concern and alarm at the comments from Jenny Macklin that ancillary health cover should be exempted from the rebate. We are very aware of the great need in the community of ancillary health services such as podiatry that enable people to remain mobile and thus live independently.
I note a letter from the President of the Australian Physiotherapy Association, who says:

The fact is there are significant waiting lists across the public hospital system for patients needing access to physiotherapy services. Including extras insurance in the government package would provide incentives for some individuals to access physiotherapy services in the private sector. By providing such an incentive, waiting lists can be reduced and the public sector may be capable of focusing on those who are in the greatest need or the most disadvantaged.

The fact is that, if you look at ancillary benefits paid in the last financial year, 1997-98, 56 per cent were for dental, 16 per cent for optical, seven per cent for physiotherapy, seven per cent for chiropractic, three per cent for pharmacy, four per cent for podiatry, 1.2 per cent for prostheses and appliances and one per cent for ambulance services. Then there are a number of things below one per cent. These are many things accessed by low income people. These are things not available on Medicare. These are items that have very limited capacity to be provided in the public system. If we did not provide assistance for them, Australians would find that they would have significantly less access than they do now.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. What benefit does the private health insurance rebate offer people who live in rural and regional Australia who have no access to private hospitals? For example, the electorates of Kalgoorlie and Gwydir have no private hospital beds at all compared to the electorate of Higgins, which has 596 private beds.

—Do you agree with the Western Australian government's argument that there is a disincentive for most rural and regional Australians to take out private health insurance, given that there are very few private hospital facilities in these areas?
—Order! Members on my right! The member for Jagajaga will come to her question.

—The member for Jagajaga will resume her seat. If the member for Jagajaga could not be heard, it was certainly not the fault of either side of the parliament. It was the fault of both sides of the parliament. The member for Jagajaga will come to her question.
—How will your proposed rebate overcome these disincentives or lack of access to hospital services?

—I thank the honourable member for her question. I make the point that if she were to spend some time in rural and regional Australia she would find there is a very deep commitment to private health insurance. That is in fact reflected in the very high membership of the private health providers in rural and regional Australia, as in fact has been indicated in this place by none other than the Prime Minister on occasion.

answer.para: The fact of the matter is that it is a reality of life for many rural people that, for quite a range of medical services they need from time to time, they do have to travel, either to capital cities or to major regional centres. The last thing they need is to be told, right in the middle of something like harvest or shearing, that an opportunity for their surgery or whatever has suddenly become available.

They need hospitals of choice, doctors of choice and some control over when they might be able to receive the attention that they need. I am absolutely amazed that you would raise the prospect of rural people being prepared to support your absurd position in relation to this issue.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. Can the Attorney inform the House of government action being taken to establish a federal magistracy? How will this further assist actions already under way and in improving access to justice?

—I thank the member for Menzies for his question. It is very pleasing to be able to inform the House of this new initiative of the government. The government has approved in principle the establishment of a federal magistracy. It is envisaged that it will service the Federal Court and the Family Court and will thereby significantly improve access to justice. The federal magistrates will be able to deal with less complex matters, freeing up judges to deal with the more difficult cases that take longer time. There will be simpler and less formal procedures in the summary court and that will be less expensive and more expeditious for the litigants.

answer.para: The proposal does sit well with other reforms the government has initiated to reduce delays. I refer in particular to the expansion of funding for alternative dispute resolution, arbitration, counselling and mediation, particularly in the Family Court. This is a very positive proposal which should provide benefits to those areas, particularly rural and regional areas, that are not serviced by judges' circuits. Speedy passage of the relevant legislation, particularly through the Senate, would help provide the benefits earlier, and I urge the opposition to get behind this excellent initiative.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, are you aware of commentary in today's media about the strength of the Australian economy and the impact that labour market deregula tion has had on jobs? What would the impact of alternative policies be on the economy?
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. The question is entirely hypothetical. Under standing order 144, it is out of order.

—The member for Calwell makes a valid point of order in that the second part of the question certainly did seek a hypothetical opinion. I invite the minister to respond to the first part of the question.

—If you would watch and listen, you would learn a lot. In answer to the first part of the question, I did see a very interesting comment piece by John Edwards this morning in the Financial Review , who of course was a key adviser to the previous Labor administration—and a biographer of Mr Keating, no less. Under the headline `The secret of Australia's success', he writes an interesting comment:

question.para: Over the two years to the June quarter, the Reserve Bank of Australia index of wages and salaries has increased nearly 10 per cent after inflation. A rapid increase in profits has gone hand in hand, however, with extremely low inflation.
I suppose that is first of all a testimony to the good economic management in the last couple of years, nearly three years. He then went on to say:
The secret of this economic magic is productivity growth.
In the year to June, productivity growth measured as real GDP per hour worked was running in excess of 3.5 per cent—triple the average of the `80s—

. . . Because of very high productivity growth, nominal labour costs per unit of output were less than inflation over the first half of this year. This meant that despite very high real earnings, real unit labour costs fell.
And how was this achieved? I read on:
While investment has been rapidly increasing, employers have also found greater freedom to reorganise work.
Visiting clients around the country, we see plenty of anecdotal evidence that the combination of computers and greater freedom to rearrange the job is changing the way Australia works.

talk.start.para: —Introduced by Labor.

—I will take the interjection in a moment. It is a very important point being made by a key adviser to the previous Labor government—it is commonsense. If you give people the freedom at work as employers and as employees to sit down and rearrange the way they work and run their businesses, then that is very good for the businesses. That boosts Australia's productivity, it makes the jobs we have more secure but, even more importantly, it opens up the opportunity for more jobs, which is exactly what this government is trying to do.

question.para: Let me respond to the interjection. The interjection was to the effect that this was all a result of what Labor was doing. In fairness, whilst Labor was always hog-tied to the trade union movement, in the early 1990s they did at least rhetorically recognise that if you gave greater freedom to people at work then this would actually be good for everybody, whether you are an employer or an employee. The reason that interjection is relevant is that that is not Labor's policy today. We are trying to build this system, and with the Workplace Relations Act we gave people more freedom at work than they have ever had before. And that is one of the reasons we are seeing such a conjunction of good economic news: we are doing better on unemployment; we are doing well on inflation; we are doing well with our exports; our businesses are doing well; more than half the jobs created have been in small business. If we encourage our small businesses, there will be more jobs in the future, and we will continue this progress.
And what is the alternative proposition? The alternative proposition—

talk.start.para: —I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. It goes to relevance. This is specifically the part of the question that you ruled out, Mr Speaker, according to the ruling that you gave to the member for Calwell. That was where the question asked for an alternative view around today, which you said was essentially hypothetical. The minister now announces that he is about to go down the road of the alternative policy, and that is against your ruling.
—I would be anticipating the minister's reply to rule what he has not said out of order. I call the minister.

—The point I make is that what we are doing is building a new system. The alternative to the new system is to go back to the old system. And that of course is the Labor Party's policy. We have the ACTU presidents all sitting on the front bench. And the Leader of the Opposition went to the ACTU council last weekend—or whenever it was—and said, `In respect of Labor's policy, we are not going to change it one jot or tittle.' In other words, they are going to stick with the regressive policy they had in the last election, which was in fact a repudiation of the policy they espoused when they were in government. And what was the consequence of that? Not more jobs but fewer jobs. This opposition is an opposition for the sake of opposition. And they are opposed to the things we are doing to help small business to create jobs. They are opposed to unfair dismissal changes, which would create jobs. They are opposed to the preservation of young people's jobs in business, particularly small business. They are opposed to the principal reforms that we need in order to create jobs. This is an opposition that has no policy but opposition for the sake of opposition.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Finance and Administration. I refer to the statement by the Treasurer that the government had adopted most of the recommendations of the Vos committee, and in some cases has gone further. What is the additional cost to the budget of adopting these changes?

—I thank the honourable member for Melbourne for his question. I can indicate that, like all that has occurred in this government for the past nearly three years, there has been a very responsible approach to all matters fiscal, a very responsible approach to the budget. That has been demonstrated time and again in the way in which the economy has been ticking over. I can assure the honourable member for Melbourne and all members of the House that the implications of the adoption of the recommendations in the Vos report are minimal to negligible.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Community Services. Minister, can you inform the House how older Australians will benefit from the introduction of the government seniors health card?

—I thank the honourable member for his interest in this particular matter. I am very pleased to report to the House that, in only three weeks time, around a quarter of a million extra Australians will be eligible to receive the Commonwealth seniors health card. This is an important initiative by this government, and I am pleased to report that it has passed the parliament. I hope the goodwill that was associated with that measure, which is unambiguously good for self-funded retirees, will soon flow through to the private health insurance rebate as well, because that is another important initiative for self-funded retirees.

answer.para: Close to a quarter of a million self-funded retirees, including about 20,000 veterans, will be eligible now for the seniors health card because the government has extended the income limit for people who are eligible to receive this card. For single people, the income limit has been extended from $22,320 to $40,000, and for a couple from $35,620 to $67,000. Those are very generous income limits now, and the effect of that will be that many self-funded retirees will be eligible for this card. One of the major benefits that they will receive is access to the concessional rate under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme—$3.20 for their prescriptions and, after 52 prescriptions, they will get them free.

One other thing I would like to report to the House is that a new application form has been prepared. It has been very much simplified. Most people will simply have to provide their taxation notice and fill out a few details. The forms will be available in Centrelink offices next week. I would encourage the seniors of Australia to access this form, and access this benefit which starts on 1 January next year.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Community Services, representing the Minister for Family and Community Services. Would the minister inform the House of the benefits of changes to child support legislation passed in the Senate this sitting? How do these changes impact on the payers, the payees and the children in my electorate of Hinkler and, for that matter, in the wider community?

—May I thank the member for Hinkler for raising this matter today which I know is of interest to many members on the government benches and, indeed, members opposite who have taken a keen interest in the Child Support Agency, the formula and many of the other issues associated with the fair delivery of income support for Australian families.

answer.para: The changes to the Child Support Scheme which have now passed the parliament and will take effect from 1 July have certainly been long awaited. There are quite a large number of changes. They reflect the very important principle which this government has always emphasised—that children are the financial responsibility of their parents. The second important principle is that government should not seek to interfere unnecessarily in people's lives. The government will continue to provide a safety net, but fundamentally the responsibility for care for children rests with their parents.

Under the new tax system, around 22,500 families will be better off as a result of the government changes to the child support arrangements. But as far as the amendments to the act—which has now been supported by the parliament—are concerned, there are a number of very significant new initiatives. Parents will be encouraged to deal directly with each other, rather than go through the Child Support Agency, whenever those arrangements are able to work satisfactorily. The amount of income that a non-custodial parent will be able to earn will rise by 10 per cent before the amount of the child support payment is calculated. The amount that a custodial parent can earn before their payments are affected will fall. Income earned overseas and the effects of negative gearing will be treated differently under the new arrangements to ensure a fairer assessment of income.

In addition, in an important new initiative, 150,000 payees will be better off because of the introduction of the minimum payment—everyone will be paying a minimum of $260 a year. There are a large number of reforms incorporated in this new legislation that go a long way to meeting the government's commitment to improve the child support arrangements. We recognise that more work still needs to be done. I would like to compliment the large group of government members who have been a part of developing these proposals and have worked long and hard in putting together a practical option that trades off the interests of both custodial parents and non-custodial parents in the best possible way to ensure the welfare of children.

We know there is more to be done. The government is committed to moving to stage 3 of the reform proposals as quickly as possible. I commend these changes to the House. I think they will make a significant improvement. I assure the House that we will be reporting back, hopefully in the next calendar year, with new initiatives to further enhance these reforms.

interjection.para: I would also make this point: for some reason the opposition want to make a mountain out of a molehill. The fact of the matter is that when you dealt with the member for Burke, Mr Speaker, the words you used were that you named him and then you went on to say that it was pursuant to 304A. On that basis, it was quite clear to me from the statement you made at the time that you were exercising your discretion under 304A. Under those circumstances, Mr Speaker, there is no basis for a motion of dissent from your ruling.

talk.start.para: —I wish to speak to that point of order, Mr Speaker. I am speaking not to either your naming of the member for Burke or to your suspension of the member for Watson. I am speaking to, and moving dissent from, your ruling which, in effect, refused permission for the member for Watson to raise a point of order for you, because it was in the raising of that point of order, which you effectively failed to permit him to do so, that you decided at that point in time to name him. In those circumstances—
—You can't debate this.

—I can debate this because I am moving a motion. The motion is that the Speaker's ruling—that is, the ruling he gave that the member for Watson was not permitted to raise a point of order—was incorrect and therefore we are dissenting from it.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. It is entirely within your discretion as to whether or not you recognise a member. On this particular occasion you neither gave a ruling nor did you recognise the member for Watson. That may be a matter of immense disappointment to the Leader of the Opposition, but the fact of the matter is that if there has been—
—The chair has exercised a great deal of tolerance in hearing points of order from both sides. Currently, the Leader of Government Business has the call.

—Mr Speaker, my point of order may escape the opposition, but the fact of the matter is that there was no ruling. If there was no ruling, there can be no motion of dissent from a ruling that you have not made. On that basis, my point of order is that the motion is out of order and cannot proceed.

—Mr Speaker, I wish to speak to the point of order raised by the Leader of the House. Mr Speaker, it is an absurd proposition to suggest that your saying to the member for Watson that if he proceeds to take a point of order you will suspend him does not constitute a ruling from which we can dissent. To pretend that we are having tolerance with regard to people raising points of order on a day when you have told someone they are going to suspended if they raise a point of order is a preposterous proposition from the Leader of the House—and he knows it is preposterous—and to allow him to come up and make speeches about two points of order on the same day that you have threatened to suspend the Chief Opposition Whip on the basis that he might raise one in the future is, I think, a preposterous point of order that you should immediately reject.
—On a point of order, Mr Speaker, under standing order 100, if there is an objection to a ruling from you it must be taken at once. I wonder how the Leader of the Opposition—
—The member for Dunkley will resume his seat. To my knowledge, the chair has not as yet given a ruling.
—I rise on a point of order. It goes to standing order 98:

interjection.para: Any Member may at any time raise a point of order which shall, until disposed of, suspend the consideration and decision of every other question.

Upon a question of order being raised, the Member called to order shall resume his or her seat and, after the question of order has been stated to the Speaker by the Member rising to the question of order, the Speaker shall give a ruling thereon.

If any objection is taken to any ruling of the Speaker, such objection must be taken at once, and a motion of dissent, to be submitted in writing, moved, which, if seconded, shall be proposed to the House, and debate thereon shall proceed forthwith.

The member for Watson stood and sought to make a point of order with you. As he raised that point of order with you, you immediately suspended him. The effect of that was to deny him his rights under section 98. We dissent from your ruling. It would probably help the business of the House if we got on with it.

talk.start.para: —I do not have a position to defend and, in that case, I am not free to defend a position. In fact, I accept the motion.
—I move:

speech.para: That the Speaker's ruling be dissented from.
I went through the relevant standing orders in my opening remarks but they bear repeating here. They are quite clear-cut. Standing order 98 says:
Any Member may at any time raise a point of order which shall, until disposed of, suspend the consideration and decision of every other question.

It is quite clear. There is no equivocation in this. There is no discretion in relation to this. It is not a case of: if the Speaker feels like hearing a point of order the Speaker will hear a point of order; if he does not feel like hearing a point of order, the Speaker won't. There is nothing in this which indicates any intention to allow any level of discretion to the chair in the conduct of a consideration of a point of order—none whatsoever.

There are many areas of standing orders which are quite opaque. This is not one of them. This is one absolutely clear-cut standing order. In case you have not got the point about what the standing order means, it goes on to talk about another couple of standing orders which relate to the way in which the House will then be conducted. Standing order 99 says:

Upon a question of order being raised, the Member called to order shall resume his or her seat, and, after the question of order has been stated to the Speaker by the Member rising to the question of order, the Speaker shall give a ruling thereon.

It then invites you, Mr Speaker, not to simply pump the member from parliament when that point of order is raised with you but actually to deliberate on whether or not the point of order is valid and rule on the matter of wheth er or not that point of order is valid. The appropriate response to the member for Watson would not have been his discharge. The appropriate response would have been to deal with that point of order. If he were then disorderly, you would be perfectly entitled to discharge the member for Watson—or any other member of this House.

You do have the authority to discharge any member of this House under two sections of standing orders, at least one of which you have used twice today. But it is hardly a fair interpretation of standing orders—in fact, it is a unique interpretation of standing orders—to suggest that what ought to happen here, before any ruling has been made on whether the member for Watson has a valid point of order, is that he simply leave the chamber.

There were plenty of reasons for him to raise a point of order on this. In fact, you yourself seemed to be indicating quite clearly that you were going to move on the particular minister. This was one occasion when the minister was not asked a question which would allow him to transverse a huge array of matters related to a goods and services tax or any other form of tax on any education materials—it was specifically about private tuition. The minister, who repeatedly takes licence in this House with the standing orders to the embarrassment of all concerned, will always be likely to have this point of order raised on him. He is a minister who, generally speaking, is a threat to speakers and a threat to good order in this House. He has a number of cousins on the frontbench as far as evading the issue of a question is concerned, but he stands out among them, head and shoulders. This is a minister for whom standing orders is a matter of levity, a matter of jest, a matter of complete irrelevance.

He occupies this House with dorothy dixers day in and day out—for hours and hours—but when he is asked something specific he always fails to answer. He does not occasionally answer; he always fails to answer. It is therefore likely that he will frequently have standing orders related to relevance raised upon him and, indeed, that is precisely what happened to him here today. At the point when the member for Watson attempted to raise the point of order of relevance, the minister had had only one point of order raised on him by the Manager of Opposition Business, who, in response to the continued flouting of the question of relevance, was depressed, annoyed and of a cast of mind not to bother pursuing it, so hopeless did he think the cause.

But that does not apply to all members of the House. Other members are entitled to raise that question as well, and that question was quite relevantly raised by the member for Watson. That is all he was talking about—a point of relevance. The member for Watson was not heckling. The member for Watson was not abusing the minister at the table. The member for Watson was not abusing the Speaker. The member for Watson was not abusing anyone across the frontbench. The member for Watson was doing something particularly simple which, I would have thought, would have been a matter of routine consideration by the House.

It is not as though the minister concerned was being disrupted by the repeated raising of points of order which had reached a point of disorderly behaviour. It is not impossible for such a set of circumstances to occur in this House. It is not something which occurs frequently, but it is possible for it to occur. It had not occurred in this case. In this case, the matter had been raised once, and there had been, after the matter was raised, a substantial period of time in which the minister avoided the question entirely—avoided the fact that this government intends to impose a GST on tuition fees where it is privately arranged, as it is by parents whose children are in government schools.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, my point of order is one of relevance. Under the standing orders, the mover of the motion is required to address the motion before the chair, namely, the dissent. He, after six minutes, has run out of things to say, so he is moving on to the minister and the question of the goods and services tax. He is clearly running out of steam and should be required to get back to the motion; otherwise, he ought to just sit down.
—The Leader of the House will resume his seat. The Leader of the Opposition is in fact ranging wider than dissent from the motion, it is true, and I ask him to draw his argument back to that point.

—I am very pleased to do that, but it is necessary, in the course of my remarks, to raise the point as to why it was relevant for the member for Watson to raise these points as a point of order. If it was not relevant for him to do so, it may well have been a disorderly intervention on his part, even though you did not warn him or in any other way deal with the person as a Speaker normally would.

speech.para: In circumstances where you consider his behaviour disorderly, it is relevant to work out whether or not there is a case for the member for Watson to be on his scrapers asking about whether or not a point of order was validly made. So let me go to the question so we can establish whether or not it was a reasonable thing for the member for Watson to be doing that and not to be pushed out of the House before he had a chance to complete his remarks. This was the question, within the standing orders framework, seeking clarification:

Minister, is it the case that the parents of a student who employ a private tutor from a company like Power Coaching or Kip McGrath, to assist their child with remedial reading at home, will have to pay a GST on the tutoring fees? Minister, can you explain why it is good policy for families to have to pay GST on remedial coaching?

What the minister was doing at the time was talking about whether or not there is a wholesale sales tax on foolscap paper. He was talking about whether or not there is a wholesale sales tax on pencils. He was telling you whether or not there is a wholesale sales tax on X, Y and Z. What he was not talking about was what he was specifically asked about and, looking at the way in which you were preparing in fact to handle the particular minister, you rather thought he might not be also. You rather thought that, on this very specific question, he might be in fact about to deviate considerably from the standing orders in relation to relevance.

talk.start.para: —On a point of order, Mr Speaker, on relevance: the Leader of the Opposition is speaking to circumstances that are not relative to your ruling. I was close enough to hear the Chief Opposition Whip. The basis of his point of order and his persistence, which is of course especially prevented—

—Order! The interjections that I am hearing from the left are taking up the time that is allocated to the Leader of the Opposition. I do not intend to hear the minister in an unlimited sense, but I will hear his point before he resumes his seat.

—Mr Speaker, if a member persistently and wilfully disregards the authority of the chair, they can be subject to 304 or 304A. The point I am making to you, sir, is that the opposition whip was trying to make a point of order on the procedures of naming. Naming is not an exclusion to the House; naming has to be moved, and it was not.

—The minister has made the point of order, which is something that I have been entertaining here, and I have been exercising a good deal more leniency towards the Leader of the Opposition than he is entitled to. The member for Watson was named on the basis of the procedures unrelated to the question that had been asked of the minister about the GST. I now invite the Leader of the Opposition to return to the dissent motion.

—It was actually dealing with both issues—the question of relevance and the detail related to naming. Your last words before you sent him out were, `If the member for Watson seeks to take a further point of order on the ruling I have given, he too will be named under standing order 304—he will be suspended under standing order 304A.'

speech.para: Mr Speaker, as it happened—and I fully understand the reasons why you did it—the handling of a point by naming was incorrect in any shape or form as far as this chamber is concerned. If you name a person in this place, and it is perfectly within your powers to do so, this person then has to be moved to be exited from it, usually by the Leader of the House. By failing to do so and to back you up, that was a problem for him and for you, but it was a perfectly relevant thing for the member for Watson to be concerned about. He was concerned about both that issue and the question of relevance, which is the subject of what we are dealing with here today.

There is just nothing in House of Representatives Practice or anywhere else to permit the dealing with of a member while raising legitimately a point of order in this place. Nor is the person concerned in this regard, the member for Watson, a prolific point taker. He has in fact raised only four points of order in the current session of parliament. What the House of Representatives Practice says here is quite clear:

Any Member may raise a point of order at any time which, until disposed of, suspends the consideration and decision of every other question. A point of order necessitates a ruling being given by the Chair and may be objected to and a motion of dissent moved. A motion of dissent must be debated and determined immediately.
There are grounds for considering that a Member taking a point of order shall not be interrupted by another Member taking a point of order on the first point of order.
Which must be said to have been offended pretty regularly here. It continues:

The basis of this point of view is that as a point of order is an appeal or a complaint to the Chair in connection with the operations of the House, a Member has a right to make the point without interruption except by the Chair and have a ruling or decision given.

Mr Speaker, it is quite clear, under House of Representatives Practice and under the standing order, that your situation is such that you must hear a proposition raised. I would have thought that, if the point of order were to be raised under either of those grounds, either the ground of relevance or the ground related to whether or not standing order 304A had been appropriately used in the process of naming, the grounds are there, amply and clearly enunciated, for a point of order to be effectively taken.

It just happens to be the case that the minister concerned is a man who provokes these sorts of situations by his continued failure to remain relevant to the questions that he is asked. He might well wish to do so on this subject because this is a subject about which the government has a great deal of embarrassment. He is likely to evade questions. He is likely to create a disorderly situation.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I take a point of order.
—You're in the wrong seat. Sit down!

—I welcome the assistance of my colleagues on geography. The embarrassment or otherwise of the government on various policy issues has got nothing to do with this motion of dissent from your ruling. I ask that you require the Leader of the Opposition to return to the question.
—The member for Parramatta will resume his seat. The Leader of the Opposition has the call. The Leader of the Opposition will focus his remarks—
—Mr Speaker, I think it is quite relevant—

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The Leader of the Opposition is not being assisted by those behind him. He has the call. I ask him to return to the essence of the dissent motion.

—I think it is relevant in a dissent motion, in these sets of circumstances where two sets of problems occur and are confronting you at the same point, to go through the circumstances in which these situations occur. If you do not comprehend those circumstances, you cannot comprehend the situation in which you find yourself making these rulings with which we have a problem. In that set of circumstances, the behaviour of the minister, both routinely and at the time, is certainly relevant as to whether or not dissent ought to be moved from your ruling.

speech.para: It is quite understandable that the minister finds it difficult to explain when he is dealing with a situation in which private schools are able to escape the GST by having their tuition in-house but, as many people in government schools and in poorer Catholic schools experience, when they experience difficulty with their education and have a need for remedial education, they go to Power Coaching College and all the other colleges, which will now cop a GST.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order—
—Mr Speaker—
—The member for Parramatta and the Minister for Forestry and Conservation will resume their seats. I plead with the Leader of the Opposition to return to the kernel of the dissent motion.

—In these circumstances it is often likely that you will find disorderly conduct which will legitimise the placing of a member of parliament outside this chamber. And then you will confront two opportunities. There is the opportunity to use standing order 304A, which is a recent standing order which assists the processes of the parliament by enabling you to put the person out without a resolution of the House. The other opportunity relates to the naming of a member, an older proposition but one which I am not sure that you have used, at least to this point. It is certainly used by Speakers to put people out of the House.

speech.para: When you name somebody, I would have thought that a halfway competent Leader of the House would be on his feet to support you instantly. But we are dealing with a dope in this situation.

talk.start.para: —The Leader of the Opposition!

—In these circumstances you do not get the protection that you deserve or need. Nevertheless, having not had the protection which you deserve or need is no reason for you to act outside the standing orders. When the standing orders clearly require you either to name somebody under that and be backed up by the House or to use 304A, you use one or the other, but you do not use both simultaneously.

speech.para: I understand that you lack the protection of a competent Leader of the House, but that is no excuse to move outside what is required as far as the standing orders are concerned. What is required is this: you are not entitled to say to the member for Watson, under the standing orders, `If the member for Watson seeks to take a further point of order on the ruling given, he too will be named under the standing orders.' You are not permitted to do that.

The member for Watson raised with you a perfectly valid point of order. That point of order went to whether or not it was appropriate for a person to be obliged to leave the chamber without a vote on naming. That is a common, average interpretation of the standing orders—a perfectly reasonable point of order to take with you. For you to rule it out in the first instance, merely getting up and raising it with you again does not of itself constitute an offence in this place under any reasonable reading of the standing orders. The House was not collapsing in disorderliness. The House was not in a situation where ministers and other members could not be heard. The House was within the dull roar that usually accompanies question time, in a reasonably orderly situation, except for one person, that being the minister. Instead of the minister being dealt with effectively under the relevant rules in relation to the standing orders, people on this side of the House were being pushed out of the place in a heavy-handed fashion and, ultimately, in a fashion ultra vires the standing orders. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Is the motion seconded?

—It is very much seconded, Mr Speaker, fundamentally and importantly, because what you have done today is to threaten the most basic right of members of parliament: the right to take a point of order. If we cannot take a point of order, Mr Speaker, what rights do we have? And do not say that we were not threatened by it. This is what took place: you said, `If the member for Watson seeks to take a further point of order, he too will be suspended under standing order 304A.' What is the proper basis? Standing order 304A says that somebody can be suspended if they are disorderly.

speech.para: Are we to believe that taking a point of order you do not like is now disorderly? Are we to believe that, on that basis, anybody who stands when you think he should not, and says, `I want to take a point of order,' might be kicked out under standing order 304A, because that is what this action says. What is worse, that is what you have done. You did not only threaten to do it, Mr Speaker, you did it.

Our concern on this day is fundamentally that we on this side of the House have been extremely tolerant since you became the Speaker. We thought it appropriate that a new Speaker should have some time to find his feet and try to establish a set of reasonable behaviour arrangements in this place in accordance with standards you wanted to set, but it has become harder and harder; and today it has become intolerably difficult. We have had the problem, which we have raised with you, about the comments that are made which seem to us to be consistently of a partisan nature, particularly during question time, and which give cause for concern to members—and which have been raised by me with you in this place.

We then had today the point of order that was raised about the minister for education, who is a serial offender, a serial ignorer of the standing orders that say answers need to be relevant. We had the quintessential case today. In the context in which the points of order and the concerns by the member for Burke, then the member for Watson, were raised, it is extremely relevant to know that we had the minister, the serial offender, up here today, not taking the slightest notice of what the question was, seeking in the first instance to redefine it so he could then answer a question to which he had an answer, instead of the one asked by the member for Dobell for which he had no answer, and, in a way that I and all my colleagues found extremely provocative, you allowed that to continue. You may have considered that my point of order was too early—

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I take a point of order on relevance. The member for Fraser has run out of puff after three minutes, half the time the Leader of the Opposition took. It is not open to the member for Fraser to canvass broader issues. As all of us who have been in the House for a long time know, when you are moving a dissent motion, you have to stick to the issue. It is a very tight little agenda.
—The Leader of the House has made his point of order.

—The member for Batman is currently taking up time that would otherwise be allocated to the member for Fraser. The member for Fraser has the call. Clearly, the same obligations the Leader of the Opposition had to address the dissent motion apply to the member for Fraser.

—Absolutely right, Mr Speaker, but we cannot discuss whether your ruling with regard to the behaviour of the member for Watson was appropriate and the ruling you gave from which we are dissenting was a valid one without looking at the context in which it took place—and that is simply what I am doing. Our concerns have consistently been as to how we can get you to rule, and how we could today get you to rule, that the minister for education needed to answer the question. That is causing significant concern, not just to the member for Burke and not just to the member for Watson.
—I must reluctantly interrupt the member for Fraser and indicate that was not at the heart of my intervention on the member for Watson.

—No, but it was the heart of the context in which the ruling took place and the response of the member for Burke took place, and the context of the response of the member for Burke to that and to the error which you made, about which no further action was taken, other than by the member for Watson. While it was an error and certain action should have followed, it is absolutely a ruling which says that you are going to put him out under standing order 304A. That implies a ruling that it is disorderly to seek to raise a point of order, because you could not warn him under standing order 304A if you were not ruling that his behaviour was disorderly in seeking to raise a point of order. That is what empowers you to act under 304A: that behaviour is disorderly. You cannot just act at whim.

speech.para: The standing order says that if a member is disorderly in his behaviour you can act under 304A, and you were therefore interpreting what we regard as a very fundamental right of members, and which I would have thought until today government members thought was a fundamental right because some of them exercise it very often—to stand and raise a point of order—and they do it persistently, provocatively, tediously and wrongly. But you have never said, `If the member for Parramatta raises a point of order, out you go,' nor should you, Mr Speaker.

I have to say that if there is one person in this House who by way of points of order goes pretty close to disorderly behaviour, we would have thought the member for Parramatta was a long way ahead of the member for Watson. He has been, from the time he came here, consistently raising points of order—and has not got one right. But the standing orders, as quoted by the Leader of the Opposition, and House of Representatives Practice as quoted by the Leader of the Opposition, combine to make it crystal clear that the right that the member for Watson was seeking to exercise was far from being an exercise in disorderly conduct which warranted you warning him, as you did, that if he sought to take another point of order he would be suspended. In fact, you once again said `named', but we know that you meant `suspended' under 304A. Far from it being disorderly, it was a basic exercise of his right.

What was the member for Watson trying to do? He was, as the Leader of the Opposition correctly points out, trying to point out that this is the worst Leader of the House in our history. He has failed to pursue the point which he should have pursued following on from that which you raised. He was seeking to raise a point of order, saying, `How are we to discern your intention, Mr Speaker, when you say one thing and do another?' You say to us and to the member for Watson, `It was clear that my intention was not to do what I said but to do what I meant.' That may be true, and we accept that it is true, but it is not disorderly for the member for Watson to say, `But, Mr Speaker, you actually said something which would have triggered a different standing order: 303 or 306, not 304A.' That is quintessentially a point of order—that you were proposing to proceed under one standing order and then proceeded under another. You may have chosen, after hearing his point of order, to say—
Government members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Fraser has the call.

—Thank you very much. I will just offer him a copy of House of Representatives Practice . He obviously has not read it. He has this provision which says he does not need to know the standing orders because he has the numbers. That is true, but it does not help. Ignorance of the law is no excuse, but it is frequently exercised.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order on relevance. The dissent motion is to your ruling, not to something that the Leader of the House has done, yet the current attack is on the Leader of the House.
—The Minister for Forestry and Conservation will resume his seat. The member for Fraser has the call.

—In the order of disorderly points of order the minister beats the member for Watson by a very long way. And I might say, in terms of disorderly behaviour today, he beats the member for Watson by a very long way. The standing order with which we are dealing, standing order 304A, was inserted, as you would know because you were here at the time, to cool down the House. It was inserted in the hope that in times of heat and anxiety for members it would help cool down the House. The excellent then Speaker, the member for Cunningham, said we should have a standing order to help cool down the House. Nobody ever thought that it was going to be used against a member seeking to raise a point of order when the House was not disorderly. The House was much less disorderly than it usually is during question time. It was much quieter than usual.

speech.para: For us, it is unreasonable to the point of intolerable to have a circumstance in which you seek to exercise standing order 304A when a member merely seeks to exercise the very basic, simple right to raise a point of order, particularly in the context where the minister speaking at the time was consistently, persistently and in breach of every standing order continuing to be irrelevant to the question and you were failing to act on that matter in a way that made everybody on this side of the House feel aggravated and anxious. It is surprising that there was not more disorder than there was—let alone that someone should have been suspended for raising a point of order.

We have sought to give you the opportunity to develop a manner of conducting this House that will be fair and reasonable and fit the procedures which you wish to establish. We have, I think, been more tolerant than many members on this side of the House think we should have been. But, Mr Speaker, you are making it more than difficult for us—you are making it impossible. And this will not be the last point of order of this nature if it continues. We will have a consistent pattern of points of order on this. I do not know what the Guinness Book of Records is for points of order on matters during question time, but I would be consulting it because this is a very serious concern. I hope the fact that we have the consistent responses and the trivialisation here does not convey to you, Mr Speaker, that we on this side of the House do not take this matter seriously and that this is not bringing to a head a series of significant major concerns which we on this side of the House have. This is not an isolated incident. This is the end of a pattern of concerns which we have had and which we have raised with you.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order on relevance. The member for Fraser is now claiming that this is but one of a series of serious events, which I must say is news to us. We would be interested to hear what those other events are, but it would not be relevant. On the point of order, the member for Fraser is not entitled to cast reflections on the chair to the extent that such an inference could be drawn from those remarks.
—The member for Fraser will return to the heart of the dissent motion.

—It is exactly relevant for us to be saying that the events which led to this dissent motion took place in a context which caused us grave concern. Whatever happens to the dissent motion, the concern will persist and you should be aware of that. That is why we moved this dissent motion today. It was not done in isolation. We were concerned about the implications of the ruling for every member here and we will be concerned any time anybody is threatened under standing order 304A on the basis of raising a point of order or acting in some other manner consistent with their rights and not in a disorderly manner. We will be concerned and we will air that concern in whatever manner the standing orders make available to us. If we continue to get a pattern of behaviour involving comments about questions or answers or comments from the Deputy Speaker about decisions made with regard to whether or not divisions should be called, we will continue to get a pattern of response from the opposition. That is not the way we want the House to operate, but I can tell you one thing for certain—it is the way it will operate if that behaviour from you and from the Deputy Speaker continues.

speech.para: We do not want the House to operate that way because we prefer to have question time continue. We like to be able to ask questions. We would actually prefer to be able to get answers, but asking questions is the second best option we have to actually getting answers. So we do not want to do it, but we will continue to do it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The government will be rejecting this motion of dissent from the ruling of the Speaker. There is absolutely no basis for it. I would like to take this opportunity to go through the basic proposition that has been put and answer the criticisms. Before I do, Mr Speaker, may I say that, in assessing the first two or three weeks of your speakership, all fair-minded members of this House would agree that you have demonstrated that the person in the Speaker's chair is balanced, fair and reasonable, and gives all members—government, opposition and the Independent—a fair opportunity to speak in the House.

speech.para: Mr Speaker, I congratulate you on your first days as Speaker. You have brought a breath of fresh air to the speakership. It has been widely commented upon, not just by members of the government but by members of the opposition—which is high praise coming from them—and I think any reasonable person would be pleased at the way in which you have exercised your discretion in the time that you have been the Speaker.

talk.start.para: —This is relevant to the motion of dissent, is it, Peter?

—It is very relevant to the dissent motion. I say that because, Mr Speaker, your dealing with the member for Watson was perfectly fair by any reasonable objective standard. While I will go over the events leading up to his suspension, the fact of the matter is that you warned the member for Watson that his pursuing the matter would be disorderly. He had raised a point of order; you had dealt with the issue; and it was very clear that he was going to continue the debate with the chair. Everybody who has been around for a while could see that—it was very obvious—and you very fairly said to him that you would consider such a pursuit of the issue as disorderly. That is what you said. That is what the Hansard will record.

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I will be looking at the Hansard , of course. But I am saying, Mr Speaker, that it was crystal clear that you warned the member for Watson about his conduct. It was very obvious that, under the guise of a further point of order, he was going to take you on. That is the guts of this whole issue. You could see it, we could see it, and so you said to the member for Watson that he would have to understand that if he wanted to pursue the matter it would obviously be disorderly. He was keen to take the matter on, and you dealt with him accordingly.

speech.para: That is not a ruling or action of the Speaker which is open to a dissent ruling. In fact, standing order 304A gives you complete discretion to expel a member for an hour for disorderly conduct or as you see fit. That is what you did and that is what has happened. In response to that, the Leader of the Opposition has fabricated a dissent motion against a non-existent ruling. I must say, Mr Speaker, that it is evidence of your fairness that you have allowed this motion to proceed. I have heard a lot of dissent motions over the years, and this is the most vacuous one I can recall. It really is a complete nonsense.

Mr Speaker, you will notice that some government members are still in the House. They are getting on with the business of government and representing their constituents. The ministers have all gone back to their offices to continue their work. When I have completed my remarks, there will be no further debate on this issue because we do not intend wasting the time of the House any further, nor do we intend that there be any further question time because far too much time has been wasted on this issue.
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —If necessary, if you want to deprive members of the opportunity to speak—but we will not be wasting further time on the shenanigans of the opposition. This is vacuous, empty and a complete waste of time, and it ought to be treated as such. I am not going to stand here and talk for 20 minutes just for the sake of filling 20 minutes. I am going to answer all the points, but I will not be speaking for the sake of speaking—which is what happened with the speeches from the Leader of the Opposition and the member for Fraser.

speech.para: To canvass the circumstances of this particular matter, the sequence of events started with the interjections by the member for Burke. He was interjecting when you, Mr Speaker, were on your feet. That was clearly disorderly, and it was quite within your discretion to deal with the member for Burke. When you used the words `name him', I took that to be the first words for moving on to standing order 304A.
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —There is an answer to that. The Leader of the Opposition said, `It was naming; therefore, as the Leader of the House, you should have moved the supporting motion.' Mr Speaker, I was obviously contemplating that, but it has been the practice in this place for some time that Speakers in a circumstance such as that would go to standing order 304A. Anybody who has been here for more than a couple of weeks would know that. Whatever words you used, Mr Speaker, you are entitled to use any words you like—including the word `named'—but, in my view, you were most likely to move to a 304A suspension for an hour. To me, that would be a reasonable expectation. Given the fact that, with a momentary pause, you went on to say that, this whole thing is a confected nonsense. That is all you could say of it.

speech.para: If the member for Watson was to be taken at his word, he was saying that it was actually a set of circumstances that warranted the full naming process. We brought in standing order 304A to deal with misdemeanours of that sort. The member for Cunningham was one of the people who initiated that change. In a hierarchy of offences, the offence of the member for Burke, in my view, was clearly a 304A offence. That is obviously how you saw it, Mr Speaker, and that is what you intended to do, and everything that flowed from that really is a complete nonsense.

I say to new members that, while loyalty will dictate that you believe everything the Leader of the Opposition has said by way of outrage at this alleged ruling, when you go back to your offices you should appreciate that there has not actually been a ruling. All that happened was that a bloke who was told, `If you pursue this matter, you will be dealt with,' was then dealt with. That is perfectly reasonable, and it is the conventional treatment in the House. Talk about making a mountain out of a molehill! This is a nonsense from start to finish, and it deserves the treatment it will get when the government exercises its majority.

The member for Burke was then dealt with under standing order 304A. The member for Watson had a point of order. You heard his point of order and you dealt with it. Then he simply wanted to continue with the issue.

talk.start.para: —It was another one.

—He wanted to raise something else; a completely new matter? He wanted to raise a point of order to talk about the weather or about the president's lunch? It was some other issue, was it? We all know the member for Watson very well, and it was quite clear from his demeanour, from what he was saying and from what had already been dealt with by the Speaker that he simply wanted to take the issue further.

speech.para: On that basis, Mr Speaker, you gave him a warning. I thought, quite frankly, you were more than fair to the member for Watson. Arguably, you could have dealt with him the first time around. But, because you had been bending over backwards to give them a fair hearing, you gave him a fair hearing. You dealt with the issue. He raised the question of the naming and the use of standing order 304A. You responded by stating what was obvious to anybody here, what your intentions were, in conformity with the practice of the House as it has grown up in recent times. You acted reasonably by any objective measure. He simply wanted to contest it.

I must say that it is not obvious to me why you people wanted to have a hullabaloo over nothing today. Had you run out of questions or something? Did you feel that you were being too vulnerable to a Kemp attack? Was that the worry? Were they worried that the Treasurer would come back and give them another going-over? Were they worried that I would get another question?

talk.start.para: —The Leader of the House will return to the motion.
—Or were they just acting out the resolution of the caucus back in 1997?
—The Leader of the House will return to the motion.

—I will return to the motion. In responding to this motion of dissent it is fair enough to ask what actually is the motive of the opposition. There is no discernible, obvious, clear basis on which they would move a motion of dissent. I think it is fair enough to ask what other possible reason they could have for moving such a motion of dissent. We don't have a ruling. They don't have a case. You warned the member for Watson before dealing with him. You have a complete discretion under standing order 304A. The Labor Party supported standing order 304A as a reasonable change to the standing orders. They put it in and we supported them. It is a reasonable means of dealing with people whose offence is not a hanging offence but a misdemeanour which should be dealt with. The sin bin for an hour is a reasonable proposition. It has had a judicious amount of use in the time since it was introduced, and today was yet another example.

speech.para: I think we have graced this motion of dissent with more than enough time, but I wanted to make one last point just to reflect on the circumstances. It is a nonsense to say that this is a demonstration of the government not supporting the Speaker. There has been one such example, but it certainly was not today. The one example, of course, was when the Labor Party was in office. Jim Cope was the Speaker, Clyde Cameron was the offender and Fred Daly was the Leader of the House. When he went to move the naming motion, Gough told him not to, and so you saw the tearing down of an independent Speaker.

talk.start.para: —I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. It goes to the relevance of the minister's contribution, which is clearly off key. If he wants to go for clarification about not supporting Speakers, turn to John Winston Howard and Halverson.

—The member for Hotham knows that he cannot continue along that line. Furthermore, I would have thought that, among the great deal of irrelevance that I have heard on both sides this afternoon, the concluding remarks of the Leader of the House were in fact by that measure relevant.

—I conclude by saying that this motion is just a complete waste of time. There was no ruling; it is a non-existent ruling. It has been fabricated by the opposition. subdebate.2.para: Motion (by Mr Reith) proposed:
(1) That a Joint Select Committee on the Retailing Sector be appointed to inquire into and report on:

(a) the degree of industry concentration within the retailing sector in Australia, with particular reference to the impact of that industry concentration on the ability of small independent retailers to compete fairly in the retail sector;
(b) overseas developments with respect to this issue, highlighting approaches adopted in OECD economies; and
(c) possible revenue-neutral courses of action by the Federal Government (ie courses of action that do not involve taxation reform).

(2) That the committee consist of 10 members, 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips, 2 members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips or by any Independent Member, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 2 Senators to be nominated by any minority group or groups or independent Senator or Senators.
(3) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(4) That the members of the committee hold office as a joint select committee until completion of the joint committee's report.
(5) That the committee elect a Government member as its chair.

(6) That the committee elect a deputy chair who shall act as chair of the committee at any time when the chair is not present at a meeting of the committee and at any time when the chair and deputy chair are not present at a meeting of the committee the members present shall elect another member to act as chair at that meeting.
(7) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the chair, or the deputy chair when acting as chair, shall have a casting vote.
(8) That 3 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.
(9) That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of 3 or more of its members and to refer to any subcommittee any matter which the committee is empowered to examine.

(10) That the committee appoint the chair of each subcommittee who shall have a casting vote only and any time when the chair of a subcommittee is not present at a meeting of the subcommittee of the members of the subcommittee present shall elect another member of that subcommittee to act as chair at that meeting.
(11) That the quorum of a subcommittee be 2 members of that subcommittee.

(12) That members of the committee who are not members of a subcommittee may participate in the proceedings of that subcommittee but shall not vote, move any motion or be counted for the purpose of a quorum.
(13) That the committee or any subcommittee have power to send for persons, papers and records.
(14) That the committee or subcommittee have power to move from place to place.
(15) That a subcommittee have power to adjourn from time to time and to sit during the adjournment of the Senate and the House of Representatives.
(16) That the committee report no later that 6 months after this resolution is agreed to by both the Senate and the House of Representatives.

(17) That the committee or any subcommittee have power to consider and make use of the evidence and records of the House of Representatives Standing Committees on Industry, Science and Technology and the Senate Economics References Committees appointed during previous Parliaments.
(18) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.
(19) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution and requesting that it concur and take action accordingly.
